children.name: tired
children.definition: /taɪəʳd/  mệt mỏi
examples: ▪ i usually feel too tired to cook dinner after a day at the office.
▪ we sat down and stretched out our tired legs.
▪ they came back from their long walk, tired but relaxed.
▪ overly tired drivers can be nearly as dangerous as drunk drivers.
get tiredstart to feel tired cảm thấy mệt mỏi
▪ can we stop soon? i’m getting really tired.

children.name: exhausted
children.definition: /ɪgˈzɔːstɪd, ɪgˈzɔːstəd/ verytired, especially because you have been doing a sport or other hard physical activity, and you have used all your energy: kiệt sức
examples: ▪ i was exhausted every day when i first started teaching, but i’m used to it now.
▪ the exhausted dancers collapsed as they stepped off the stage.
exhausted from/by kiệt sức bởi
▪ the five of them were still exhausted from their 36-hour train ride.
completely/absolutely exhausted hoàn toàn kiệt sức
▪ we had been walking for over 20 miles, and we were completely exhausted.

children.name: knackered
children.definition: /ˈnækəʳd/  british very tired:
examples: kiệt sức
▪ i’ve been up since four o'clock this morning - i’m absolutely knackered!
▪ when you’re training a team sometimes it’s good to push them until they’re knackered.

children.name: tired out/worn out
children.definition: /ˌtaɪəʳd ˈaʊt, ˌwɔːʳn ˈaʊt/  very tired, especially after a lot of hard work, physical exercise, or travelling:
examples: kiệt sức
▪ come in and sit down. you look worn out.
▪ the men had been working in the fields all day and they were tired out.
tired out/worn out from/by kiệt sức bởi
▪ susan and lloyd were both tired out from feeding, bathing, and putting the children to bed.

children.name: shattered
children.definition: /ˈʃætəʳd/  british very tired, especially as a result of mental effort or worry: suy nhược
examples: ▪ when he came out of the exam he felt shattered.
▪ i’ve had a terrible day at the office and i’m absolutely shattered.

children.name: weary
children.definition: /ˈwɪəri/  written so tired after a very long period of working, travelling, or great mental effort that you feel you can hardly continue with what you are doing: mệt mỏi, mệt nhọc
examples: ▪ after the hike the two were so weary they fell asleep immediately.
▪ snow in boston closed down the airport, causing even more delays for weary travellers.
grow weary trở nên mệt mỏi
▪ my head grew weary from trying to follow his arguments.
wearily[adverb] một cách mệt mỏi
▪ a middle-aged waitress came wearily over to them to take their order.

children.name: drained
children.definition: /dreɪnd/  very tired and feeling as if all your energy has gone, especially as a result of an unpleasant emotional experience, such as being worried, upset, or shocked: bòn rút sức lực, kiệt quệ
examples: ▪ by the end of the day i felt drained, with nothing to show for all my work.
▪ after losing the game, coach saylor came to the press conference looking and sounding emotionally drained.

children.name: beat/pooped/bushed
children.definition: /biːt, puːpt, bʊʃt/  american informal very tired: đuối sức
examples: ▪ wow, i’m pooped. i don’t feel like going to the gym tonight.
▪ you look beat - what have you been doing?
▪ will you excuse me? i’m bushed - i think i’ll go to bed.

children.name: be dead on your feet/be ready to drop
children.definition: /biː ˌded ɒn jɔːʳ ˈfiːt, biː ˌredi tə ˈdrɒpǁ-ˈdrɑːp/  informal to be so tired that you are almost unable to stay standing: mệt đến đi không nổi, đứng không vữa, sắp ngã
examples: ▪ after fourteen hours of non-stop work i was dead on my feet.
▪ for goodness’ sake go home! you look ready to drop.

children.name: tired
children.definition: /taɪəʳd/  mệt mỏi
examples: ▪ the kids were really tired, so we sent them to bed.
▪ i tried to watch the news on tv, but i was too tired to stay awake.

children.name: sleepy
children.definition: /ˈsliːpi/  if you are sleepy, you want to sleep immediately and your eyes are starting to close: buồn ngủ, uể oải
examples: ▪ ‘aren’t you sleepy?’ ‘no, i took a nap this afternoon.’
▪ it’s no easy task getting three sleepy children out of the car and into the house.
▪ we arrived at the hotel late at night, and were too sleepy to notice how beautiful it was.
sleepily [adverb] một cách uể oải
▪ ‘what time is it?’ she said sleepily.

children.name: drowsy
children.definition: /ˈdraʊzi/  starting to sleep because you are in a warm place or because you have drunk alcohol or taken medicine:
examples: buồn ngủ
▪ you shouldn’t drive after taking these pills - they can make you drowsy.
▪ len had drunk too much wine, and he felt cosy and drowsy in spite of the coffee.

children.name: half-asleep
children.definition: /ˌhɑːf əˈsliːp◂ǁˌhæf-/  very nearly asleep because you are tired and sleepy: nửa tỉnh nửa mê
examples: ▪ ‘wyatt, what is it?’ sue called, half-asleep, from the bedroom.
▪ moira was half-asleep when the phone rang and it took her a few seconds to realize what it was.

children.name: can hardly/can barely/can’t keep your eyes open
children.definition: /kən ˌhɑːʳdli, kən ˌbeəʳli, ˌkɑːnt kiːp jɔːr ˈaɪz ˌəʊpənǁˌkænt-/  to feel so tired that you find it hard to stay awake: không mở mắt nổi
examples: ▪ i can’t keep my eyes open - i’ve got to go to bed.
▪ the kids were still full of energy, but julie and i could hardly keep our eyes open.
▪ by the time we finally got home, i could barely keep my eyes open.

children.name: tiring
children.definition: /ˈtaɪərɪŋ/ somethingthat is tiring makes you feel tired:
examples: làm mệt mỏi
▪ the journey was really tiring.
▪ sam couldn’t wait for the whole tiring ordeal to be over.
a tiring day/week etc một ngày, tuần mệt mỏi
▪ i’ve had such a tiring day. i just want to take a bath and go to bed.

children.name: exhausting
children.definition: /ɪgˈzɔːstɪŋ/ somethingthat is exhausting makes you feel very weak and very tired: kiệt sức
examples: ▪ she’s just returned from another exhausting lecture tour.
▪ i had to drive nine hours without a break - it was exhausting.
▪ starting a small business can be the most physically and mentally exhausting task you’ve ever done.

children.name: hard
children.definition: /hɑːʳd/  a hardday, journey etcis one that makes you feel very tired because you have to work very hard, travel a long distance, or deal with a lot of problems:
examples: mệt mỏi
▪ taking care of a two-year-old is hard work.
▪ it was a long hard walk back to the nearest town.
▪ when i come home from a hard day at work, i don’t feel like talking to anyone.

children.name: wearing
children.definition: /ˈweərɪŋ/  a person, activity, or situation that is wearing is very tiring because it uses up a lot of your mental energy: làm cho kiệt sức
examples: ▪ i find her constant questions and chatter rather wearing.
▪ kids of that age can be very wearing, can’t they?

children.name: exhaustion
children.definition: /ɪgˈzɔːstʃən/  the feeling of being very tired: kiệt sức
examples: ▪ the soldiers were suffering from exhaustion after long days and nights of marching.
▪ the signs of chronic exhaustion showed in martha’s face.
from/with exhaustion
▪ one of the players collapsed with exhaustion and had to be carried off the field.

children.name: tiredness
children.definition: /ˈtaɪəʳdnɪs, ˈtaɪəʳdnəs/  sự mệt mỏi
examples: ▪ tiredness and headaches are common signs of stress.
▪ camomile tea soothes the nerves and relieves tiredness.
▪ a terrible tiredness had overcome her, leaving her no energy for extra activities.

children.name: drowsiness
children.definition: /ˈdraʊzinɪs, ˈdraʊzinəs/  the feeling of wanting to sleep that you sometimes get when you are in a warm place or when you have drunk alcohol or taken medicine: buồn ngủ
examples: ▪ the drug can cause drowsiness.
▪ robert stopped fighting the drowsiness and sank back in the soft chair.

children.name: fatigue
children.definition: /fəˈtiːg/  a feeling of being very tired and weak - used especially in medical contexts: sự mệt mỏi, mệt nhọc
examples: ▪ symptoms of the illness include fever, fatigue, and loss of appetite.
▪ driving in stressful conditions can lead to muscle fatigue.
▪ she seemed depressed and was beginning to show signs of fatigue.

children.name: lethargy
children.definition: /ˈleθəʳdʒi/  formal extreme tiredness that makes you feel very lazy, so that you do not want to do anything and you are not interested in anything: uể oải
examples: ▪ another common symptom of a hangover is lethargy and muscular weakness.
▪ it is not unusual for new mothers to go to the doctor complaining of tiredness, lethargy, and mild depression.

children.name: jet-lag
children.definition: /ˈdʒet læg/  a feeling of tiredness and confusion which you sometimes get when you fly to a part of the world where the time is different from the place you have left: mệt mỏi, uể oải (sau khi bay, do không thích ứng với môi trường mới)
examples: ▪ i always get jet-lag when i fly from london to new york. jet-lagged [adjective] suffering from jet-lag:
▪ on the first morning of the conference, most of us were still jet-lagged.

children.name: burnout
children.definition: /ˈbɜːʳnaʊt/  when you have worked so hard over a long period of time that you become too mentally and physically tired to continue: kiệt sức
examples: ▪ young boys recruited at an early age by soccer clubs often suffer from burnout before they’re out of their teens.

children.name: tired and having no interest in anything
lethargic
children.definition: /lɪˈθɑːʳdʒɪk, ləˈθɑːʳdʒɪk/  feeling tired and lazy, as if you have no interest in doing anything: uể oải, biếng nhác
examples: ▪ all this hot weather is making me feel lethargic.
▪ patients with depression may be lethargic during the day and unable to sleep at night.
▪ the spectacular play inspired his lethargic teammates to start playing harder.

children.name: listless
children.definition: /ˈlɪstləs/  feeling tired and not interested in anything, especially because you are ill: thờ ơ, lơ đãng
examples: ▪ tim is listless on the job and keeps making dumb mistakes.
▪ the last few years of my mother’s life she was tired and listless most of the time.
▪ she had to keep thinking up new ways to hold the attention of her listless pupils.

children.name: tired
children.definition: /taɪəʳd/  mệt mỏi
examples: ▪ i’ve never seen him look so tired.
tired eyes/face etc đôi mắt, gương mặt mệt mỏi
▪ look at their tired little faces.
▪ she had tired-looking bags under her eyes.

children.name: washed-out
children.definition: /ˌwɒʃt ˈaʊtǁˌwɑːʃt-/  especially british looking tired and unhealthy: xanh xao, gầy hao
examples: ▪ the last time i saw helena she was looking pretty washed-out. is she alright?

children.name: bleary-eyed
children.definition: /ˌblɪəri ˈaɪd◂/  with red, half-open eyes, especially as a result of lack of sleep: đôi mắt thâm quần
examples: ▪ after twelve hours of driving jean was bleary-eyed and stiff.
▪ the bleary-eyed engineers were still hard at work when everyone else arrived the next day.

children.name: drawn
children.definition: /drɔːn/  someone who looks drawn is tired from illness, worry, or working too hard, and their face looks thin and pale: gầy gò, co rúm lại
examples: ▪ terry’s face was pale and drawn when she finally arrived.
▪ the emergency meeting had lasted all night, and the president looked drawn as he read the statement.

children.name: get tired
children.definition: /ˌget ˈtaɪəʳd/  trở nên mệt mỏi
examples: ▪ if you get tired, just stop for a while.
▪ we talked until we both got tired and decided to go to bed.
▪ since her illness, she finds that she gets tired really easily.

children.name: flag
children.definition: /flæg/  to start to get tired, especially if you are doing something that needs a lot of energy: yếu đi, trở nên mệt
examples: ▪ jenny taught for four hours straight without flagging.
▪ by the fifth game, i could see that my opponent was beginning to flag.

children.name: tire yourself out/wear yourself out/exhaust yourself
children.definition: /ˌtaɪəʳ jɔːʳself ˈaʊt, ˌweəʳ jɔːʳself ˈaʊt, ɪgˈzɔːst jɔːʳself/  to become tired by doing things that take a lot of effort: mệt hết cả hơi
examples: ▪ the baby’s stopped crying. he must have tired himself out.
▪ you’re going to wear yourself out if you keep working so hard.
▪ my poor mother had exhausted herself trying to get ready for company.

children.name: burn out/burn yourself out
children.definition: /ˌbɜːʳn ˈaʊt, ˌbɜːʳn jɔːʳself ˈaʊt/  to become tired, ill, and unable to continue, as a result of working too hard for too long, especially because you want very much to be successful: cố quá sức
examples: ▪ if you don’t stop working nights and weekends, you’ll burn yourself out.
▪ most of these high-flying young executives burn out before they’re 30.
burnt-out/burned out/ˌbɜːʳnt ˈaʊt◂, ˌbɜːʳnd ˈaʊt◂/ [adjective] cố quá sức
▪ most of the school’s teachers have been there for years and are burnt out.

children.name: run out of steam
children.definition: /ˌrʌn aʊt əv ˈstiːm/  to become so tired that you do not have enough energy to finish what you are doing, especially when you have been working hard for a long time: mệt bở hơi tai
examples: ▪ the home team seemed to run out of steam well before the game was over.
▪ gail started the project with a lot of energy and enthusiasm, but at some point she just ran out of steam.

children.name: tire yourself
children.definition: /ˈtaɪəʳ jɔːʳself/  to become tired because of things that you do: khiến bản thân mệt mỏi
examples: ▪ get plenty of rest and try not to tire yourself unnecessarily.

children.name: tire/wear out
children.definition: /ˌtaɪər, ˌweər ˈaʊt/  làm cho kiệt sức
examples: tire/wear somebody out làm cho ai đó kiệt sức
▪ their constant quarrelling is wearing us out.
tire/wear out somebodylàm cho ai đó kiệt sức
▪ the thin air at high altitudes usually tires out people who are not used to the mountains.

children.name: exhaust
children.definition: /ɪgˈzɔːst/  to make someone feel very tired: làm kiệt sức
examples: ▪ the effort of swimming against the current exhausted him.
it exhausts somebody to do something làm cho ai đó kiệt sức vì làm việc gì
▪ it exhausted him to talk for too long, but he loved hearing all the theater gossip.

children.name: tire
children.definition: /taɪəʳ/  to make someone feel tired, especially someone who gets tired easily because they are old or ill: làm mệt mỏi (già yếu)
examples: ▪ i won’t tire you with a long visit. i just wanted to stop in and see how you were doing.

children.name: take it out ofsb/do somebody in
children.definition: /ˌteɪk ɪt ˈaʊt əv somebody, ˌduː somebody ˈɪn/  informal to make you feel as if you have no energy left: làm cảm thấy không còn sức lực
examples: ▪ dale’s a construction worker. you know, that sort of work really takes it out of you.
▪ it wasn’t the cooking so much as all the cleaning up that did me in.

children.name: it nearly killed me
children.definition: /ɪt ˌnɪəʳli ˈkɪld miː/ spoken use this to say that doing a very hard job or activity made you feel extremely tired: mệt muốn chết
examples: ▪ it nearly killed me carrying that fridge up the stairs!
